interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Frozen
Review Date: 2014/05/15
Store: Kristen Bell  (Actor),     Josh Gad  (Actor),     Chris Buck  (Director, Writer),     Jennifer Lee  (Director, Writer)    &                   1                  more   Rated:    PG    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Award Winners in Movies & TV, Oscar Central, Past Oscar Winners
Product Description: ['Product Description', "Fearless optimist Anna teams up with Kristoff in an epic journey, encountering Everest-like conditions, and a hilarious snowman named Olaf in a race to find Anna's sister Elsa, whose icy powers have trapped the kingdom in eternal winter.", 'Amazon.com', 'A sweet, magical film filled with great music, likable characters, and striking effects,', 'Frozen', 'is a fairy tale about overcoming obstacles and the power of true love. Princesses Anna and Elsa are sisters and the closest friends until one day Elsa discovers that she can no longer control her power to create ice and snow. Terrified for the safety of her sister and everyone around her, Elsa isolates herself and vows to never feel any sort of passionate emotion again in hopes of suppressing her powers. But when Elsa comes of age and is set to be crowned queen, she must open the gates of the palace and let in the public, not to mention her sister Anna. Things go horribly wrong and Anna pursues her sister into the mountains in an attempt to save Elsa and reverse the deep freeze that Elsa has inadvertently released on the kingdom of Arendelle. Along the way, Anna joins forces with Kristoff (Jonathan Groff), an ice seller with a strangely close relationship with his reindeer Sven, and Olaf (Josh Gad), a goofy snowman whom she suddenly remembers from early childhood. In the end, Anna and Elsa discover that only by embracing their deepest feelings do they have a chance of saving themselves and the kingdom. Inspired by "The Snow Queen" story by Hans Christian Andersen, the film has plenty of quirky, lovable characters along with a nice blend of corny humor, serious sentiment, suspense, and peril. Kristen Bell and Idina Menzel deliver rousing performances of great music that includes original songs by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez and an original score by Christophe Beck, and the visual effects are simply stunning.', 'Frozen', 'definitely succeeds in captivating audiences young, old, and every age in between.', '--Tami Horiuchi']
Average Rating: 4.7
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Animation', 'Format': 'Multiple Formats, Animated, Color, Dolby, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen, DTS Surround Sound', 'Contributor': 'Jennifer Lee, Hans Christian Andersen, Kristen Bell, Menzel, John Lasseter, Chris Williams, Aimee Scribner, Jonathan Groff, Gad, Idina Menzel, Ciarán Hinds, Santino Fontana, Maia Wilson, Josh Gad, Alan Tudyk, Shane Morris, Groff, Bell, Stephen J. Anderson, Chris BuckJennifer Lee, Hans Christian Andersen, Kristen Bell, Menzel, John Lasseter, Chris Williams, Aimee Scribner, Jonathan Groff, Gad, Idina Menzel, Ciarán Hinds, Santino Fontana, Maia Wilson, Josh Gad, Alan Tudyk, Shane Morris, Groff, Bell, Stephen J. Anderson, Chris Buck  See more', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 5.1), French (Dolby Digital 5.1), Spanish (Dolby Digital 5.1)', 'Runtime': '1 hour and 42 minutes', 'Aspect Ratio': '2.20:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG (Parental Guidance Suggested)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': '11941900', 'Director': 'Chris Buck, Jennifer Lee', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, Animated, Color, Dolby, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen, DTS Surround Sound', 'Run time': '1 hour and 42 minutes', 'Release date': 'March 18, 2014', 'Actors': 'Kristen Bell, Josh Gad, Idina Menzel, Jonathan Groff, Santino Fontana', 'Subtitles': 'French, Spanish, English', 'Producers': 'Aimee Scribner, John Lasseter', 'Studio': 'Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment', 'Writers': 'Chris Buck, Hans Christian Andersen, Jennifer Lee, Shane Morris', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: This film is great - and that is coming from a Disney hater! I haven't liked a Disney movie since The Fox & The Hound. However, the storyline of Frozen is awesome. At first you think this is going to be another big sister is a monster and poor little sister needs a man to save her and make all her decisions for her. Then you see that big sister is just in need of love and little sister is just in need of her big sister. The cute boy turns into the villian and the regular joe turns into the hottie with a HUGE heart! Plus the snowman is wonderfully loving and encouraging! I love that this fairytale's happy ending is family empowering! I love that this fairytale's happy ending doesn't stomp on any one difference in characters. except the rottenness of a selfish person. I really love this movie and so does my 14yo son!
Review Title: Not your everyday Disney movie
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------

profile:
**User Profile Summary**

This user exhibits a strong appreciation for animated films, particularly those from Disney, showcasing a shift in their perspective since they previously identified as a Disney skeptic. Key preferences include:

- **Themes of Empowerment:** They favor narratives that focus on family bonds and empowerment over traditional romantic tropes, as evidenced by their enthusiasm for the storyline that subverts typical fairy tale roles.
- **Character Depth:** The user values character development, especially stories that highlight emotional connections and personal growth rather than superficial relationships.
- **Positive Messages:** They are drawn to films that convey uplifting messages about love, acceptance, and support among family members, as illustrated by their positive take on the film's resolution.
- **Humor and Heart:** The appreciation for humor in characters (specifically the snowman) indicates a preference for light-hearted elements balanced with emotional depth.

Overall, this user's viewing preferences lean toward films that challenge stereotypes and provide meaningful life lessons, reflecting a thoughtful engagement with storytelling in animated cinema. Their experience with "Frozen" suggests a willingness to embrace and recommend films that resonate on both emotional and thematic levels.
